ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I will never watch movies the same way. As a STEM major who had never engaged in analysis of film before, this course changed the way I think about plot, characters, cinematography, acting and directing. There really is no need for previous experience, just desire to push oneself beyond the superficial viewing and watch closely.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The movies on the syllabus are very interesting and engaging, and most of them are films you probably have not watched before. Thematically they are nicely connected and easy to juxtapose. The work is not too bad, but it could be spread more evenly over the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This class deals with interesting themes and films, but it felt disorganized and a bit all over the place. Additionally, at least half of the films dealt with the Greece and its diaspora, which isn't inherent in the title. I think greater geographic distribution of the films would be beneficial to the class.
Yes, it's not bad it terms of work, and you will learn a lot while touching upon interesting topics and watching movies you haven't heard of!
I loved this class! Such a cool way to talk about migration as well as an introduction into a genre of film that I had never been exposed to.
